prompt: <description>**Part 1: Rectangular Metal Plate with Four Holes** The first part of our CAD assembly is a rectangular metal plate with four evenly spaced holes along its edges. We will start by creating a new coordinate system. **Coordinate System** For the coordinate system, we have an Euler Angle of [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] degrees, and a Translation Vector of [0.0, 0.0, 0.0]. This will be the base for our 2D sketch. **Sketch** In this sketch, we have one face (face\\_1), which contains five loops (loop\\_1 to loop\\_5). * **Loop 1:** + This loop consists of four lines (line\\_1 to line\\_4), forming a rectangle. - Line\\_1: Start Point [0.0, 0.0], End Point [0.3643, 0.0] - Line\\_2: Start Point [0.3643, 0.0], End Point [0.3643, 0.75] - Line\\_3: Start Point [0.3643, 0.75], End Point [0.0, 0.75] - Line\\_4: Start Point [0.0, 0.75], End Point [0.0, 0.0] * **Loop 2, 3, 4, and 5:** + Each loop contains one circle. - Circle\\_1 (common to all loops): Center [0.0429, 0.2357], Radius 0.0214 + The circles are placed at different positions along the X and Y axes to create four evenly spaced holes along the edges of the rectangle. **Extrusion** Next, we will transform the 2D sketch into a 3D model by extruding it. * **Extrusion Depth:** + Extrude\\_depth\\_towards\\_normal: 0.0536 + Extrude\\_depth\\_opposite\\_normal: 0.0 **Dimensions** Our rectangular metal plate has the following dimensions: * Length: 0.75 units (derived from the longer side of the rectangle) * Width: 0.75 units (derived from the shorter side of the rectangle) * Height: 0.0536 units (specified in the extrusion property) The above instructions provide all necessary information for generating an accurate parametric CAD model of the first part. Note that the loops and circles in this part are interconnected and form a single, integral unit.</description>
